net.grinder.statistics
Class StatisticsSetImplementation

java.lang.Object
  net.grinder.statistics.StatisticsSetImplementation
All Implemented Interfaces:
ImmutableStatisticsSet, StatisticsSet
final class StatisticsSetImplementation
extends Object
implements StatisticsSet

Store an array of raw statistics as unsigned long or double values. Clients can access individual values using an index obtained from a StatisticsIndexMap.

Author:
Philip Aston

reset

public void reset()
Reset this StatisticsSet to default values. Allows instance to be reused.

Specified by:
reset in interface StatisticsSet

snapshot

public StatisticsSet snapshot()
Clone this object. We don't use Object.clone() as that's such a hog's arse of a mechanism. It prevents us from using final variables, requires a lot of casting, and that we catch CloneNotSupported exceptions - even if we know they won't be thrown.

Specified by:
snapshot in interface ImmutableStatisticsSet
Returns:
A copy of this StatisticsSetImplementation.

getValue

public long getValue(StatisticsIndexMap.LongIndex index)
Return the value specified by index.

Unfortunately the Java language specification does not make long access atomic, so we must synchronise.

add

public void add(ImmutableStatisticsSet operand)
Add the values of another StatisticsSet to ours. Assumes we don't need to synchronise access to operand.

Currently the implementation assumes that the argument is actually a StatisticsSetImplementation.

Synchronised to ensure we don't lose information.

.

Specified by:
add in interface StatisticsSet
Parameters:
operand - The statistics set value to add.

isZero

public boolean isZero()
Description copied from interface: ImmutableStatisticsSet
Return whether all the statistics are zero. This allows us to optimise cases where there's no information to be processed.

This method can return false, even if all of the statistics are zero; but if it returns true they are guaranteed to be zero.

Specified by:
isZero in interface ImmutableStatisticsSet
Returns:
true => all values are zero.

writeExternal

void writeExternal(ObjectOutput out,
                   Serialiser serialiser)
             throws IOException
Efficient externalisation method used by StatisticsSetFactory.writeStatisticsExternal(java.io.ObjectOutput, net.grinder.statistics.StatisticsSetImplementation).

Why not implement java.io.Externalizable? Because I consider it morally dubious:

  • It requires a public default constructor which either has to bypass class constraints, or discover external dependencies through singletons or a service registry
  • readExternal should only be called by the serialisation engine, but needs to be public.

Synchronised to ensure a consistent view.

If you change this, update TestStatisticsMap serialVersionUID.

Parameters:
out - Handle to the output stream.
serialiser - Serialiser helper object.
Throws:
IOException - If an error occurs.
See Also:
StatisticsSetImplementation(StatisticsIndexMap, ObjectInput, Serialiser)
